docs.lead_paragraph: A federal health official’s decision came as a vindication for people who have claimed that their cancers were caused by exposure to the dust cloud and debris at ground zero.

headline.seo: Ruling to Allow 9/11 Health Fund to Cover Cancers
headline.main: Sept. 11 Health Fund Given Clearance to Cover Cancer
headline.print_headline: 9/11 Health Fund Given Clearance To Cover Cancer

docs.abstract: Federal ruling clears the way for 50 different types of cancer to be added to the list of sicknesses covered by a $4.3 billion fund set up to compensate and treat people exposed to the toxic smoke, dust and fumes in the months after the Sept 11 terrorist attacks; ruling is made by Dr John Howard, director of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.
docs.snippet: A federal health official’s decision came as a vindication for people who have claimed that their cancers were caused by exposure to the dust cloud and debris at ground zero.

keywords.name: organizations

keywords.value: James Zadroga 9-11 Health and Compensation Act
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Newly released messages between administration officials and drug industry lobbyists underscore the compromises underlying President Obama’s effort to overhaul health care.

headline.seo: E-Mails Highlight Extent of Obama’s Deal With Industry on Health Care
headline.main: Obama Was Pushed by Drug Industry, E-Mails Suggest
headline.print_headline: Obama Pushed By Drug Lobby, E-Mails Suggest

docs.abstract: Batches of e-mail messages and other documents obtained and released by House Republicans offer a window into the compromises struck between the Obama administration and the pharmaceutical industry as the administration pursued its health care overhaul; deal-making, which largely took place in 2009, represents a pivotal moment in which Obama first came to grips with the messy reality of Washington policy-making.
docs.snippet: Newly released messages between administration officials and drug industry lobbyists underscore the compromises underlying President Obama’s effort to overhaul health care.

keywords.name: subject

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: Emails released by the House Energy and Commerce Committee open a window into the negotiations between the White House, Senate Democrats and pharmaceutical industry in 2009 as part of President Obama’s drive to overhaul the health care system.

headline.seo: E-Mails Offer Look at Deal-Making Over Health Care Law
headline.main: E-Mails Offer Look at Deal-Making Over Health Care Law

docs.snippet: Emails released by the House Energy and Commerce Committee open a window into the negotiations between the White House, Senate Democrats and pharmaceutical industry in 2009 as part of President Obama’s drive to overhaul the health care system.

headline.main: 2012 May Lack Drama, but Not Significance
headline.print_headline: Political Memo: Not the ’08 Campaign, but More May Be at Stake

docs.abstract: Though the current election season is producing very few goose bumps, the 2012 presidential race is shaping up to be more important to the direction of the country than the 2008 campaign was.
docs.snippet: Though the current election season is producing very few goose bumps, the 2012 presidential race is shaping up to be more important to the direction of the country than the 2008 campaign was.

docs.abstract: Health care costs continue to soar, yet we do not yet seem to have found a ceiling at which Americans are ready to start setting boundaries on what care is available to whom.
docs.snippet: Health care costs continue to soar, yet we do not yet seem to have found a ceiling at which Americans are ready to start setting boundaries on what care is available to whom.

docs.lead_paragraph: The House wastes time passing legislation designed to satisfy the ideological desires of conservative voters while the bills that need to become law get blocked.
docs.abstract: Editorial criticizes House Republicans for wasting time passing legislation designed to satisfy the ideological desires of conservative voters while blocking bills that need to become law; contends that their actions show that they have little interest in governing.
docs.snippet: The House wastes time passing legislation designed to satisfy the ideological desires of conservative voters while the bills that need to become law get blocked.

docs.lead_paragraph: A choice by some private unions to back Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, aiding an offensive against their public-sector brethren, exposes a deepening fissure in the labor movement.

headline.seo: Union Donations to Business Group Show Fracture in Labor Movement
headline.main: Donations to Key Cuomo Ally Show a Rift Among Unions
headline.print_headline: Cuomo Ally in Fighting Unions Got Labor’s Financial Support

docs.abstract: Choice by some private-sector unions to back New York State Gov Andrew M Cuomo, aiding an offensive against their public-sector brethren, exposes a deepening fissure in the labor movement; Committee to Save New York aid to a business coalition shows how battles over government spending, especially at the state level, have deepened longstanding tensions in the labor movement.
docs.snippet: A choice by some private unions to back Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, aiding an offensive against their public-sector brethren, exposes a deepening fissure in the labor movement.

keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: The latest assault on President Obama’s health care law appears to have little chance of approval in the Senate.

headline.seo: Bill to Repeal Tax on Medical Devices Clears House
headline.main: House Acts to Repeal Medical-Device Tax
headline.print_headline: House Acts to Repeal Medical-Device Tax

docs.abstract: House, in another assault on Pres Obama's health care law, votes 270 to 146 to repeal a new tax on medical devices; bill has little chance of approval in the Senate.
docs.snippet: The latest assault on President Obama’s health care law appears to have little chance of approval in the Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: Three-quarters of Americans say the Supreme Court’s decisions are sometimes influenced by personal or political views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline.seo: Approval Rating for Supreme Court Hits Just 44% in Poll
headline.main: Approval Rating for Justices Hits Just 44% in New Poll
headline.print_headline: Approval Rating For Justices Hits just 44% In Poll

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds that just 44 percent of Americans approve of the job the Supreme Court is doing and three-quarters say the justices’ decisions are sometimes influenced by their personal or political views; findings are a fresh indication that the court’s standing with the public has slipped significantly in the past quarter-century.
docs.snippet: Three-quarters of Americans say the Supreme Court’s decisions are sometimes influenced by personal or political views, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll.
